flawed_nl_solution:
The sum of the ratios representing the amount of money the three has is 4+5+6=<<4+5+6=17>>17
If the total amount of money they have is $75, the amount of money Cara has represented by the fraction 4/17 is 4/17*$75=$300/17<<4/17*75=300/17>>300/17
Similarly, the amount of money Janet has represented by the fraction 5/17 of the total ratio is 5/17*$75=$375/17<<5/17*75=375/17>>375/17
Combined, Cara and Janet have $300/17+375/17=$675/17<<300/17+375/17=675/17>>675/17
If Cara and Janet buy goods worth $675/17 and sells them at 80% of the buying price, the selling price of the goods will be 80/100*$675/17=$540/17<<675/17*80/100=540/17>>540/17
Since they bought the goods at $675/17 and sold them at $540/17, Janet and Cara would run at a loss of $675/17-$540/17=$135/17<<675/17-540/17=135/17>>135/17
#### 135/17

error_details.explanation: The result of this computation should be 15, not 17. This appears to be a minor miscalculation.
